case_title: MUHAMMAD NAWAZ and others vs MUHAMMAD IKHLAQ and others
complaint_summary: Petitioners challenged the classification of Sana Ullah as a 'temporary Lambardar' instead of 'permanent Lambardar' under the Land Revenue Act.
investigation_summary: The case involved examining rules 17, 19, and 21 of the Land Revenue Act to determine the legality of the classification of Lambardars.
judgment_summary: The court ruled that the terms 'temporary Lambardar' and 'permanent Lambardar' are not recognized under the Land Revenue Act. The succession of Lambardars is governed by rule 19(2) and the principle of primogeniture. Naseer Ahmad was appointed Lambardar as the eldest son of the eldest son of the outgoing Lambardar Sana Ullah.
Decision_or_verdict: Petition dismissed. Revision petition of Naseer Ahmad accepted.
legal_arguments: Rule 17 applies to first appointments of Lambardars and does not distinguish between estates owned by Government or private individuals.
Rule 19 governs succession and applies the principle of primogeniture for privately owned estates.
The law does not recognize the terms 'temporary' or 'permanent' Lambardar.
key_issues: Application of rules 17 and 19 for Lambardar succession
legal_issue: Recognition of 'temporary Lambardar' and 'permanent Lambardar' under the Land Revenue Act and Rules.

key_points.rule_17: No distinction in qualifications for Lambardar appointments across estates owned by Government or private individuals.
key_points.rule_19: Succession criteria differ based on estate ownership (Government-owned vs privately-owned).
key_points.rule_21: Special contingency rule unrelated to normal circumstances under rules 17 and 19.
key_points.primogeniture: Mandatory for succession in privately-owned estates under rule 19(2).
key_points.misinterpretation: Deputy Commissioner and Commissioner erred in considering Sana Ullah a 'temporary Lambardar'.

facts.initial_appointment: Sana Ullah appointed on probation in 1908 and confirmed in 1910.
facts.ownership_change: Village transitioned from Government-owned to privately-owned before Sana Ullah's death in 1987.
facts.succession_error: Officials wrongly applied rule 17 instead of rule 19(2).

decision.successor: Naseer Ahmad appointed Lambardar in place of Sana Ullah.

legal_terms.Lambardar: A village headman responsible for revenue collection and administration.
legal_terms.Primogeniture: The right of succession belonging to the firstborn child.

words_and_phrases.Temporary Lambardar: A term not recognized under the Land Revenue Act.
words_and_phrases.Permanent Lambardar: A term not recognized under the Land Revenue Act.

summary_vector_notes: The judgment clarifies that the terms 'temporary' and 'permanent' Lambardar are not legally recognized under the Land Revenue Act. Succession is governed by rule 19(2), applying the principle of primogeniture for privately owned estates. Naseer Ahmad was appointed Lambardar as per the rules.
